sections.title: What are T-Bills?
sections.content: T-Bills are short-term debt instruments issued by the government to raise funds. They typically mature in less than one year.

sections.title: How They Work
sections.content: Investors buy T-Bills at a discount and receive the full face value at maturity. The difference represents the earned interest.

title: Bonds
subtitle: Long-term government or corporate debt instruments

sections.title: Overview
sections.content: Bonds are long-term investments that pay periodic interest and return the principal at maturity.

sections.title: Risk and Return
sections.content: Bonds generally offer lower risk compared to stocks but can vary depending on the issuer's credit rating.
